title: How to Make a Pinhole Lens for Your SLR Camera

steps.headline: Find the center of the body cap.
Drill a hole measuring approximately 1/4" / 6.35mm.
steps.description:
Using the center mark that you created in the previous step, drill a hole in the body cap. Use something under the body cap to protect your working surface if needed. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b9\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b9\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Cut a square piece measuring approximately 3/4"x 3/4" / 1.9 centimeter (0.7 in) x 1.9cm (approximately) from the aluminum sheet.
Make a dimple in the center of the aluminum piece.
Sand the dimple.
steps.description: Using very fine grit wet/dry sanding paper (emery cloth) of 600-800 grain or finer, gently sand the dimple flush with the surface of the aluminum surface.

steps.headline: After the dimple has been sanded away, a small hole should appear in the aluminum.
steps.description: Use the needle once more to gently round out the hole (both sides). The optimum diameter of the pinhole depends on the distance from the pinhole to the film surface (digital sensor). For most (D)SLR cameras that is somewhere around 50mm. Using a pinhole calculator, the optimum pinhole size is apx .3mm. A #13 sewing needle should pass through a .3mm hole but a #12 needle should not. The size does not have to be exact at any rate, any hole close to .3mm will work just fine. If the hole is too small, gently use the needle again to enlarge the hole and sand both sides smooth. If the hole is too large, try the lens to see how well it works, or discard the piece and cut a new one. What is important is to make the hole as round as possible and to keep the edges smooth and flush with the surface. Jagged edges will cause diffraction effects and show up on the final image.

steps.headline: After you have sized the pinhole correctly, clean the aluminum piece and the pinhole with rubbing alcohol and blowing through the pinhole.
steps.description: Doing this is important since residue can get in the pinhole and cause image distortions or worse the residue can get on your camera sensor and require a cleaning.

steps.headline: Apply adhesive.
steps.description: Using a toothpick, or something equivalent, sparingly spread the adhesive around the edge of the aluminum piece, being careful not to get any adhesive near the pinhole. Use silicone adhesive as you can easily remove the pinhole from the body cap and remove the adhesive from the body cap if you ever need or want to.

steps.headline: Carefully place the aluminum piece into the center backside of the body cap.
steps.description: Make sure to center the pinhole in the drilled hole in the body cap. Try to be exact when positioning the first time, in order to keep the adhesive from getting all over the body cap and possibly into the pinhole.

steps.headline: Tape the aluminum piece in place while the adhesive dries.
steps.description: Do a final check to make sure the pinhole is still centered on the hole in the body cap.

steps.headline: After the adhesive dries, carefully remove the tape.
Cut a very small square piece of tape and cover the pinhole.
Mask the body cap.
steps.description: Leave the aluminum piece exposed so it can be painted black.

steps.headline: Spray flat black paint over the aluminum piece.
steps.description: This will greatly improve the image quality.

steps.headline: Remove the small square piece of tape covering the pinhole.
Using a black permanent marker, dot the remaining aluminum surface so it is black.
steps.description:
The ink sticks better when dotted onto the surface rather than wiped because the aluminum surface has no tooth for the ink to adhere to. Be careful not to dot over the pinhole. This area does not have to be perfect as it will not reflect as much light as the entire aluminum surface would. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/67\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-16Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-16Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/67\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-16Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-16Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Remove all the masking tape and do a final cleaning.
steps.description:
Attach the body cap to the camera body. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/6c\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-17Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-17Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/6c\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-17Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-17Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Put your SLR in manual mode and set the shutter speed to 2 seconds to start.

tyn: Body cap that fits your camera
Flat black paint / large sharpie marker
Tape (to hold aluminum while glue dries and mask body cap during painting)
text:
Find the center of the body cap. Mark a dimple in the center of the body cap with the center punch tool. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/2/2f/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Using a nail or similar tool is also effective. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/e/ee/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Drill a hole measuring approximately 1/4" / 6.35mm. Using the center mark that you created in the previous step, drill a hole in the body cap. Use something under the body cap to protect your working surface if needed. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b9/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/b/b9/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-2Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cut a square piece measuring approximately 3/4"x 3/4" / 1.9 centimeter (0.7 in) x 1.9cm (approximately) from the aluminum sheet. Using a soda can with the top and bottom cut off, cut a 3/4" (1.9 cm) square to 1" (2.5cm) square piece. The size does not need to be exact nor exactly square, however the size must be small enough to fit flush inside the body cap yet large enough to hold while sanding. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0d/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/0/0d/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Round the corners of the square piece for safety. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/40/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Make a dimple in the center of the aluminum piece. Take a sturdy sharp needle, and slowly use a twisting motion with gentle pressure, to make a dimple in the center of the aluminum. Go slowly and steadily so as not to create a hole that is too large. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/8/87/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} The dimple should be just visible on the underside of the aluminum piece. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/18/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/18/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet2.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Do not push the needle all the way through; there shouldn't be a visible hole at this point, only a dimple. Sand the dimple. Using very fine grit wet/dry sanding paper (emery cloth) of 600-800 grain or finer, gently sand the dimple flush with the surface of the aluminum surface. After the dimple has been sanded away, a small hole should appear in the aluminum. Use the needle once more to gently round out the hole (both sides). The optimum diameter of the pinhole depends on the distance from the pinhole to the film surface (digital sensor). For most (D)SLR cameras that is somewhere around 50mm. Using a pinhole calculator, the optimum pinhole size is apx .3mm. A #13 sewing needle should pass through a .3mm hole but a #12 needle should not. The size does not have to be exact at any rate, any hole close to .3mm will work just fine. If the hole is too small, gently use the needle again to enlarge the hole and sand both sides smooth. If the hole is too large, try the lens to see how well it works, or discard the piece and cut a new one. What is important is to make the hole as round as possible and to keep the edges smooth and flush with the surface. Jagged edges will cause diffraction effects and show up on the final image. After you have sized the pinhole correctly, clean the aluminum piece and the pinhole with rubbing alcohol and blowing through the pinhole. Doing this is important since residue can get in the pinhole and cause image distortions or worse the residue can get on your camera sensor and require a cleaning. Apply adhesive. Using a toothpick, or something equivalent, sparingly spread the adhesive around the edge of the aluminum piece, being careful not to get any adhesive near the pinhole. Use silicone adhesive as you can easily remove the pinhole from the body cap and remove the adhesive from the body cap if you ever need or want to. Carefully place the aluminum piece into the center backside of the body cap. Make sure to center the pinhole in the drilled hole in the body cap. Try to be exact when positioning the first time, in order to keep the adhesive from getting all over the body cap and possibly into the pinhole. Tape the aluminum piece in place while the adhesive dries. Do a final check to make sure the pinhole is still centered on the hole in the body cap. After the adhesive dries, carefully remove the tape. Cut a very small square piece of tape and cover the pinhole. Mask the body cap. Leave the aluminum piece exposed so it can be painted black. Spray flat black paint over the aluminum piece. This will greatly improve the image quality. Remove the small square piece of tape covering the pinhole. Using a black permanent marker, dot the remaining aluminum surface so it is black. The ink sticks better when dotted onto the surface rather than wiped because the aluminum surface has no tooth for the ink to adhere to. Be careful not to dot over the pinhole. This area does not have to be perfect as it will not reflect as much light as the entire aluminum surface would. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-16Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-16Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/67/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-16Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-16Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Remove all the masking tape and do a final cleaning. Attach the body cap to the camera body. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-17Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-17Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/6/6c/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-17Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-17Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Put your SLR in manual mode and set the shutter speed to 2 seconds to start. Take a photo. Look at the histogram. If the graph indicates that the image is over-exposed (the histogram will show data bunched to the extreme right) or under-exposed (histogram data is bunched to the left), adjust the shutter speed to compensate. Once the exposure is set you can use this exposure while shooting in similar light conditions. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/3/3a/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Depending on how bright the scene is your exposure time may vary from several seconds to just under a second. The yellow flower photo shown here was exposed for 1/2 a second at ISO 400 in full sun. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet2.jpg/v4-460px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/a/af/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet2.jpg/v4-760px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} The sun through the leaves photo was exposed for 1/15 of a second at ISO 400. If your scene lighting changes, recheck the histogram and adjust shutter speed to compensate.
sentences: Find the center of the body cap.
Mark a dimple in the center of the body cap with the center punch tool.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2f\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/2\/2f\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Using a nail or similar tool is also effective.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/ee\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet2.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/e\/ee\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet2.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-1Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Drill a hole measuring approximately 1/4" / 6.35mm.
Using the center mark that you created in the previous step, drill a hole in the body cap.
Use something under the body cap to protect your working surface if needed.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b9\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/b\/b9\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-2Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-2Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Cut a square piece measuring approximately 3/4"x 3/4" / 1.9 centimeter (0.7 in) x 1.9cm (approximately) from the aluminum sheet.
Using a soda can with the top and bottom cut off, cut a 3/4" (1.9 cm) square to 1" (2.5cm) square piece.
The size does not need to be exact nor exactly square, however the size must be small enough to fit flush inside the body cap yet large enough to hold while sanding.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0d\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/0\/0d\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Round the corners of the square piece for safety.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/40\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet2.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/40\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet2.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-3Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Make a dimple in the center of the aluminum piece.
Take a sturdy sharp needle, and slowly use a twisting motion with gentle pressure, to make a dimple in the center of the aluminum.
Go slowly and steadily so as not to create a hole that is too large.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/87\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/8\/87\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} The dimple should be just visible on the underside of the aluminum piece.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/18\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/1\/18\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet2.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-4Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Do not push the needle all the way through; there shouldn't be a visible hole at this point, only a dimple.
Sand the dimple.
Using very fine grit wet/dry sanding paper (emery cloth) of 600-800 grain or finer, gently sand the dimple flush with the surface of the aluminum surface.
After the dimple has been sanded away, a small hole should appear in the aluminum.
Use the needle once more to gently round out the hole (both sides).
The optimum diameter of the pinhole depends on the distance from the pinhole to the film surface (digital sensor).
For most (D)SLR cameras that is somewhere around 50mm.
Using a pinhole calculator, the optimum pinhole size is apx .3mm.
A #13 sewing needle should pass through a .3mm hole but a #12 needle should not.
The size does not have to be exact at any rate, any hole close to .3mm will work just fine.
If the hole is too small, gently use the needle again to enlarge the hole and sand both sides smooth.
If the hole is too large, try the lens to see how well it works, or discard the piece and cut a new one.
What is important is to make the hole as round as possible and to keep the edges smooth and flush with the surface.
Jagged edges will cause diffraction effects and show up on the final image.
After you have sized the pinhole correctly, clean the aluminum piece and the pinhole with rubbing alcohol and blowing through the pinhole.
Doing this is important since residue can get in the pinhole and cause image distortions or worse the residue can get on your camera sensor and require a cleaning.
Apply adhesive.
Using a toothpick, or something equivalent, sparingly spread the adhesive around the edge of the aluminum piece, being careful not to get any adhesive near the pinhole.
Use silicone adhesive as you can easily remove the pinhole from the body cap and remove the adhesive from the body cap if you ever need or want to.
Carefully place the aluminum piece into the center backside of the body cap.
Make sure to center the pinhole in the drilled hole in the body cap.
Try to be exact when positioning the first time, in order to keep the adhesive from getting all over the body cap and possibly into the pinhole.
Tape the aluminum piece in place while the adhesive dries.
Do a final check to make sure the pinhole is still centered on the hole in the body cap.
After the adhesive dries, carefully remove the tape.
Cut a very small square piece of tape and cover the pinhole.
Mask the body cap.
Leave the aluminum piece exposed so it can be painted black.
Spray flat black paint over the aluminum piece.
This will greatly improve the image quality.
Remove the small square piece of tape covering the pinhole.
Using a black permanent marker, dot the remaining aluminum surface so it is black.
The ink sticks better when dotted onto the surface rather than wiped because the aluminum surface has no tooth for the ink to adhere to.
Be careful not to dot over the pinhole.
This area does not have to be perfect as it will not reflect as much light as the entire aluminum surface would.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/67\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-16Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-16Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/67\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-16Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-16Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Remove all the masking tape and do a final cleaning.
Attach the body cap to the camera body.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/6c\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-17Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-17Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/6\/6c\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-17Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-17Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Put your SLR in manual mode and set the shutter speed to 2 seconds to start.
Take a photo.
Look at the histogram.

If the graph indicates that the image is over-exposed (the histogram will show data bunched to the extreme right) or under-exposed (histogram data is bunched to the left), adjust the shutter speed to compensate.
Once the exposure is set you can use this exposure while shooting in similar light conditions.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/3a\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet1.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/3\/3a\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet1.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} Depending on how bright the scene is your exposure time may vary from several seconds to just under a second.
The yellow flower photo shown here was exposed for 1/2 a second at ISO 400 in full sun.

{"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/af\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet2.jpg\/v4-460px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet2.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/a\/af\/Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet2.jpg\/v4-760px-Make-a-Pinhole-Lens-for-Your-SLR-Camera-Step-18Bullet2.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":307,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":507.3626373626374,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons<\/a>
\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"} The sun through the leaves photo was exposed for 1/15 of a second at ISO 400.
If your scene lighting changes, recheck the histogram and adjust shutter speed to compensate.
